newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bavarian CSU - EMU delay would jeopardise project.
newsitem.headline: Bavarian CSU - EMU delay would jeopardise project.

text.p: Bavaria's Christian Social Union (CSU) party, a core part of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling coalition, said on Wednesday delay to European economic and monetary union (EMU) could spell an end to the whole project.
"In practice, it must be assumed any delay in the euro would jeopardise the whole currency union project," CSU deputy chairman and European deputy Ingo Friedrich said in a statement.

"Thus a responsible German policy in this area must be based on a strict insistence both on the criteria and start-date (for EMU)," he added, referring to agreed economic convergence targets and the planned 1999 start-date.

The statement follows reports last week the CSU, which is led by Finance Minister Theo Waigel, would push for a delay of EMU following the election of the Socialists in France, whom they fear would seek to loosen the criteria for entry into EMU.
A CSU spokesman said however the statement was issued in the light of the wider discussion over an EMU delay in Germany and was not directed at its party members in particular.
